original_title: Sri Lanka rates to follow faster fall in inflation: CB Governor
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s interest rates will fall in parallel with faster than expected easing of inflation and a debt restructuring process which will be made known shortly, Central Bank Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe said.
“Inflation is coming down faster than expected, with that we also see interest rate from the peak, easing down,” Governor Weerasinghe told an economic forum on May 09.
“Especially after we announce the complete debt restructuring process, we think market interest rates would come down faster.”
“We are hoping in the second half inflation will normalize in line with our inflation predictions.”
In the fourth quarter of 2023, inflation is expected to fall to single digits according to central bank projections.
Sri Lanka’s interest rates usually spike in the wake of currency crises that emerge from liquidity injections made to keep rates below developments in domestic credit.

The rupee has also been allowed to appreciate to around 320 amid negative private credit from March. In past currency crises, after confidence is restored in the currency, rates start to fall as capital flight ends and new money comes in.

However, in the current crisis, domestic debt restructuring fears have pushed up risk premiums. In past currency crises, banks and other investors buy heavily into government securities as private credit slows or turns negative.
Rates in banks are showing signs of peaking according to central bank data.
Sri Lanka is expected unveil an complete debt restructuring plan later in May.Related Sri Lanka bank deposits protected in any domestic debt optimization: CB Governor
Governor Weerasinghe said any debt optimization bank deposits and the stability of the banking sector will be safeguarded. (Colombo/May10/2023)
